headline.kicker: ON THE UNABOMBER'S TRACK: THE VICTIMS
headline.main: At the Places Where Bombs Killed, a Day for Memories and Nervous Optimism

results.snippet: They are an unusual club, the victims of the Unabomber. Mostly academics, a few corporate executives, and one a secretary who happened to open the wrong package, they are spread at random across the country and linked only by the fact that their...
results.lead_paragraph: They are an unusual club, the victims of the Unabomber. Mostly academics, a few corporate executives, and one a secretary who happened to open the wrong package, they are spread at random across the country and linked only by the fact that their lives were damaged or in some cases devastated by a package from someone with a penchant for evil. Most have never even met. But with the news yesterday that the dark odyssey of nearly 18 years might finally be ending, their common bond came flooding back with vivid memories of that terrible moment when the bomber shook their lives.

results.snippet: It didn't match Orson Welles's "War of the Worlds" Halloween hoax, but a Queens weekly newspaper provoked a small panic last week with an article on Disney's ground-breaking ceremony for a theme park at Fort Totten. The date atop the page: April...
results.lead_paragraph: It didn't match Orson Welles's "War of the Worlds" Halloween hoax, but a Queens weekly newspaper provoked a small panic last week with an article on Disney's ground-breaking ceremony for a theme park at Fort Totten. The date atop the page: April Fool's Day. "I knew right away that it was a joke," Dr. Barry M. Stein, a Bayside exercise physiologist, said of the article in The Queens Tribune. If the picture did not look fake enough, Dr. Stein said, the byline -- Vito Powers -- should have been a giveaway.

headline.main: In the Air: From Flying Machines to Balloons to Space Capsules

results.snippet: THE Bruce Museum's arcade gallery has been transformed into a lighted runway, where aircraft models suspended from beams seem ready for take-off. Viewers are  invited to inspect a time line illustrating the history of aviation from Leonardo da...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Bruce Museum's arcade gallery has been transformed into a lighted runway, where aircraft models suspended from beams seem ready for take-off. Viewers are invited to inspect a time line illustrating the history of aviation from Leonardo da Vinci's flying machines to balloons to outer space capsules. "On Outstretched Wings," the second installment of a year-long exploration of flight (displayed through June 2) joins "Flight: Ready for Take-Off," (which continues through August and focuses on flight). The new exhibition traces the human conquest of air and space, global and local. "This exhibition covering the history of flight was made to accompany "Ready for Take-Off," said Marianne Smith, the museum's curator of science, who organized the show assisted by Lisette Henrey, the museum's associate curator of education. Ms. Smith described it as a natural evolution and said it would be followed by an exhibition called "Birds in Flight."

headline.main: Engineering School Offers 4 Years of Free Tuition

results.snippet: The Rowan College School of Engineering in southern New Jersey has no building, no accreditation and will not even open until the fall, but yesterday  it made a bold move to entice a bright class of freshmen: it has offered all entering...
results.lead_paragraph: The Rowan College School of Engineering in southern New Jersey has no building, no accreditation and will not even open until the fall, but yesterday it made a bold move to entice a bright class of freshmen: it has offered all entering undergraduates four years of free tuition. Officials at the state college in Glassboro, N.J., formerly known as Glassboro State College, said they would be offering four-year scholarships worth a total of $14,000 each to all 156 students whom the engineering school has accepted. Many of those students will choose other colleges, but officials said they expect at least 75 students to commit to Rowan's engineering school.

headline.main: Habitats/1158 Fifth Avenue;A Real Estate Brokerette and Her New Maisonette

results.snippet: ETKIN CHAMOGLU, age 11, likes to tell the story of how she found her family its new 10-room duplex apartment:         "My friend Ashley called. Actually, she came to school and talked about this  place being for sale, and I said, 'O.K., can you give...
results.lead_paragraph: ETKIN CHAMOGLU, age 11, likes to tell the story of how she found her family its new 10-room duplex apartment: "My friend Ashley called. Actually, she came to school and talked about this place being for sale, and I said, 'O.K., can you give me the brochure?' Then we went to a museum, the Guggenheim, with my mom and she gave us the brochure and my mom liked it and we bought it."

headline.main: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport;0 to Springtime in 4.8 Seconds

results.snippet: FINALLY there is a car in my driveway that no one really needs.         For some time now, I have bemoaned the trend toward sport utility vehicles, to pickup trucks and all-wheel-drive wagons; to, well, automotive plebianism.
results.lead_paragraph: FINALLY there is a car in my driveway that no one really needs. For some time now, I have bemoaned the trend toward sport utility vehicles, to pickup trucks and all-wheel-drive wagons; to, well, automotive plebianism.

headline.main: Broadway Is Bursting With Energy And Youth

results.snippet: FOR the six days every week that 11-year-old Larissa Auble is on Broadway in  "Show Boat," her mother, Louise Auble, must make the 70-mile round-trip commute  from their Livingston, N.J., home to get her daughter to and from the Gershwin Theater on...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR the six days every week that 11-year-old Larissa Auble is on Broadway in "Show Boat," her mother, Louise Auble, must make the 70-mile round-trip commute from their Livingston, N.J., home to get her daughter to and from the Gershwin Theater on West 51st Street. Yolette Hodge, a single parent, and her sons, Edwin, 11, and Aldis, 9, battled poverty and periodic homelessness before the boys also won parts in "Show Boat."
